content.description: On the left side of the short overhang, the arete feature goes with an off-balance move to the triangle. Head right across the lip to a committing top-out over the bushes.
content.protection: Pad + spot. A fall from the top into the bushes would be nasty.
content.location: Short overhang in the middle of the east side of the RRMFP complex.

content.description: Start on good holds on the right side of the overhang and make a long move to the jug at the lip. Move left and top out over the bushes.
content.protection: Pad + spot, there are some nasty bushes to fall in if you blow the top.
content.location: Short overhang in the middle of the complex, on the east side.

content.description: Low start on the horn under the prow. An early knee-bar leads to a jug on the arete then work across the face heading left to good holds on the upper left part of the wall.
content.protection: Pad + spot. The landing slopes down from left to right but is relatively clear of large rocks.
content.location: Lowest boulder downhill in the group. SDS on the right arete. Descend by walking left then downclimb/jump at the next boulder.

content.description: The most uphill boulder in this grouping has a tall face with a large hole at the bottom. A low start on the triangle jug to a few toothy holds will put you on the tall face with pockets and varnished jugs. PM shade.
content.protection: 2 pads + spot. There is a large block just left of the fall line, so a pad draped over might be wise.
content.location: Most uphill boulder in RRMFP Complex on the east face. Start on the jug in the hole. Descend by walking across to the west side of the boulder, step down-right to access the back of the tall hallway, and scramble down.

content.description: Ray Ringle Memorial Face Problem Complex consists of four boulders and a hidden "room" which may be good shelter in a storm. Most of the problems are in the shade in the afternoon. RRMFP is one of the better problems in the area. High Lonesome Sound is sharp and tall.
